posts.name: dragon
posts.cooked:
Patrick Breyer – 6 Jul 21

Chatcontrol: European Parliament approves mass surveillance of private...

Today, the European Parliament approved the ePrivacy Derogation, allowing providers of e-mail and messaging services to automatically search all personal messages of each citizen for presumed suspect content and report suspected cases to the police....

europarl.europa.eu – 7 Jul 21

Parliament approves rules to tackle child sexual abuse online | News |...

Parliament has approved new rules enabling online providers to continue to voluntarily detect, remove and report child sexual abuse material online.

What will happen now? Will Signal be forced to drop encryption?

link_counts.title: Chatcontrol: European Parliament approves mass surveillance of private communications – Patrick Breyer
Parliament approves rules to tackle child sexual abuse online | News | European Parliament

posts.cooked: No, not yet. Mail and messenger providers are allowed to scan messages. But the EU commission already thinks about forcing providers to scan messages and to bypass encryption. So, this will be another step. But NOW the band begins to play!!!
is there an official source or European newspaper other than an industry or personal blog to break the news?

posts.name: dragon
posts.cooked: I added it as second link

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
fireball:

But the EU commission already thinks about forcing providers to scan messages and to bypass encryption

I wonder how they do that if the encryption and transport are not done by the same company: GnuPG encrypted email, Silence for sms messages. Then the provider can’t build a backdoor into the encryption even if they want to.

Signal can, of course, just ignore it, just as they ignore the latest Indian laws about snooping. When you have no representation in the UE they can declare their laws hold in the entire universe al they want but they can’t enforce them.

posts.name: dragon
posts.cooked: Well they could remove Signal from Apple and Google stores

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked: That would be a first. But even if they do Signal can start to distribute outside Google Play for Android. And the market share of iOS is very small outside the US anyway.

posts.name: lol
posts.cooked:
signal will now keep backdoor

signal have to stop service in usa . EU if you want secure …
posts.edit_reason: A post was merged in by Herohtar

posts.cooked: urges a new post on the official blog where Signal states its position on the matter

We’ll have to wait and see with what the commission will come up. Getting access to confidential, private, encrypted messages (no matter how) will be the final step to mass surveillance. If this will be realizable…?

posts.name: lol
posts.cooked: Its time to take hard step.if signal care about your privacy they should remove from this stores…dont break our trust …

posts.name: mattie
posts.cooked: What don’t you trust about the store builds? It’s open source and people will always be able to ensure that the build matches (the Android build at least)

anon53652:

And the market share of iOS is very small outside the US anyway.

According to Mobile Operating System Market Share Europe | StatCounter Global Stats, iOS has a market share of 30% in Europe. In the US, the market share of iOS is roughly 58% (see Mobile Operating System Market Share United States Of America | StatCounter Global Stats).

30% is a lot!
If this law allows companies to search messages doesn’t mean that they have to, right?

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
I imagine they will at some point implement a way to generate hashes of media and flag anyone who shares a hash that’s on the prohibited list

Edit:
Yup, that’s literally in the article. Enjoy your communication freedom folks, future generations won’t have as much of it as we do.

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
Meteor0id:

I imagine they will at some point implement a way to generate hashes of media and flag anyone who shares a hash that’s on the prohibited list

I hope not, it will increase the number of users (and also support requests) of my fork significantly because this would definitely something that I’d remove.

Meteor0id:

a hash that’s on the prohibited list

Yep, and what will be on the prohibited list?
Are we allowed to share memes making fun of the POTUS, or will that be illegal? Are memes making fun of the Russian President allowed? Maybe they will be in the Russian prohibited list but not in those of other countries?
Or perhaps history and archaeology buffs will be flagged and investigated for sharing photos of ancient Roman mosaics that include what we today call svastikas in their design?

This is why we need open source, and apps or forks of apps that don’t conform to this madness.

@TeeJay82
At the moment they don’t have to! But the EU commission is working on it!

@anon53652
Which fork did you develop?
posts.edit_reason: A post was merged in by Herohtar

posts.cooked:
fireball:

At the moment they don’t have to! But the EU commission is working on it!

Do you have a source?

posts.name: temp
posts.cooked:
DonDino:

This is why we need open source, and apps or forks of apps that don’t conform to this madness.

I know I’m beating a dead horse here, that’s also the more reason for signal to embrace forks that access its infrastructure, or consider allowing alternatives, including federation.
This has to make news. Back in 2012, EU citizens protested vocally against the ACTA regulation. The EU public can stops the creep towards mass surveillance under the expected pretexts of tackling abuse, fighting terrorism, etc. The problem is the EU parliament couldn’t have picked a better time, when picketing against such regulation carries the greater risk of mass infection.
